And let Bianca take her sister's room.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Shall sweet Bianca practise how to bride it?

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: She shall, Lucentio. Come, gentlemen, let's go. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters,
and all foul ways! Was ever man so beaten? was
ever man so rayed? was ever man so weary? I am
sent before to make a fire, and they are coming
after to warm them. Now, were not I a little pot
and soon hot, my very lips might freeze to my
teeth, my tongue to the roof of my mouth, my
heart in my belly, ere I should come by a fire
to thaw me: but I, with blowing the fire, shall
warm myself; for, considering the weather, a
taller man than I will take cold. Holla, ho! Curtis.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Who is that calls so coldly?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: A piece of ice: if thou doubt it, thou mayst
slide from my shoulder to my heel with no greater a
run but my head and my neck. A fire, good Curtis.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Is my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: O, ay, Curtis, ay: and therefore fire, fire; cast on
no water.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Is she so hot a shrew as she's reported?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: She was, good Curtis, before this frost: but,
thou knowest, winter tames man, woman and beast;
for it hath tamed my old master and my new mistress
and myself, fellow Curtis.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Away, you three-inch fool! I am no beast.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Am I but three inches? why, thy horn is a foot;
and so long am I at the least. But wilt thou make
a fire, or shall I complain on thee to our
mistress, whose hand, she being now at hand, thou
shalt soon feel, to thy cold comfort, for being slow
in thy hot office?

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: I prithee, good Grumio, tell me, how goes the world?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: A cold world, Curtis, in every office but thine;
and therefore fire: do thy duty, and have thy
duty; for my master and mistress are almost frozen to
death.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: There's fire ready; and therefore, good Grumio, the
news.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Why, “Jack, boy! ho! boy!” and as much news as wilt
thou.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Come, you are so full of cony-catching!

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Why, therefore fire; for I have caught extreme
cold. Where's the cook? is supper ready, the
house trimmed, rushes strewed, cobwebs swept;
the servingmen in their new fustian, their white
stockings, and every officer his wedding garment
on? Be the jacks fair within, the gills fair without,
the carpets laid, and every thing in order?

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: All ready; and therefore, I pray thee, news.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: First, know, my horse is tired; my master and mistress
fallen out.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: How?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Out of their saddles into the dirt; and thereby hangs
a tale.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Let's ha't, good Grumio.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Lend thine ear.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Here.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: There.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: This 'tis to feel a tale, not to hear a tale.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: And therefore 'tis called a sensible tale: and
this cuff was but to knock at your ear, and
beseech listening. Now I begin: Imprimis, we came
down a foul hill, my master riding behind my
mistress, —

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Both of one horse?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Why, a horse.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Tell thou the tale: but hadst thou not crossed
me, thou shouldst have heard how her horse fell
and she under her horse; thou shouldst have heard
in how miry a place, how she was bemoiled, how
he left her with the horse upon her, how he beat
me because her horse stumbled, how she waded
through the dirt to pluck him off me, how he
swore, how she prayed, that never prayed before,
how I cried, how the horses ran away, how her
bridle was burst, how I lost my crupper, with
many things of worthy memory, which now shall
die in oblivion and thou return unexperienced to thy
grave.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: By this reckoning he is more shrew than she.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Ay; and that thou and the proudest of you all
shall find when he comes home. But what talk I
of this? Call forth Nathaniel, Joseph, Nicholas,
Philip, Walter, Sugarsop and the rest: let their
heads be sleekly combed, their blue coats brushed
and their garters of an indifferent knit: let
them curtsy with their left legs and not presume
to touch a hair of my master's horse-tail till they
kiss their hands. Are they all ready?

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: They are.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Call them forth.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master to
countenance my mistress.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Why, she hath a face of her own.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: Who knows not that?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Thou, it seems, that calls for company to countenance
her.

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: I call them forth to credit her.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Why, she comes to borrow nothing of them.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Welcome home, Grumio!

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.ab: How now, Grumio!

sp.speaker: Joseph
sp.ab: What, Grumio!

sp.speaker: Nicholas
sp.ab: Fellow Grumio!

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: How now, old lad?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Welcome, you; — how now, you; — what, you; — fellow,
you; — and thus much for greeting. Now, my spruce
companions, is all ready, and all things neat?

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: All things is ready. How near is our master?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: E'en at hand, alighted by this; and therefore be
not — Cock's passion, silence! I hear my master.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Where be these knaves? What, no man at door
To hold my stirrup nor to take my horse!
Where is Nathaniel, Gregory, Philip?

sp.speaker: All Servants
sp.ab: Here, here, sir; here, sir.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Here, sir! here, sir! here, sir! here, sir!
You loggerheaded and unpolished grooms!
What, no attendance? no regard? no duty?
Where is the foolish knave I sent before?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: Here, sir; as foolish as I was before.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: You peasant swain! you whoreson malt-horse drudge!
Did I not bid thee meet me in the park,
And bring along these rascal knaves with thee?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: Nathaniel's coat, sir, was not fully made,
And Gabriel's pumps were all unpinked i' the heel;
There was no link to colour Peter's hat,
And Walter's dagger was not come from sheathing:
There were none fine but Adam, Ralph, and Gregory;
The rest were ragged, old, and beggarly;
Yet, as they are, here are they come to meet you.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in. Exeunt Servants. Singing
Where is the life that late I led —
Where are those — Sit down, Kate, and welcome. —
Soud, soud, soud, soud! Re-enter Servants with supper.
Why, when, I say? Nay, good sweet Kate, be merry.
Off with my boots, you rogues! you villains, when? Sings

lg.l: It was the friar of orders grey,
As he forth walked on his way: —

sp.l: Out, you rogue! you pluck my foot awry:
Take that, and mend the plucking off the other. Strikes him.
Be merry, Kate. Some water, here; what, ho!
Where's my spaniel Troilus? Sirrah, get you hence,
And bid my cousin Ferdinand come hither:
One, Kate, that you must kiss, and be acquainted with.
Where are my slippers? Shall I have some water? Enter one with water.
Come, Kate, and wash, and welcome heartily.
You whoreson villain! will you let it fall? Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Patience, I pray you; 'twas a fault unwilling.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: A whoreson beetle-headed, flap-eared knave!
Come, Kate, sit down; I know you have a stomach.
Will you give thanks, sweet Kate; or else shall I?
What's this? mutton?

sp.speaker: First Servant
sp.l: Ay.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: 'Tis burnt; and so is all the meat.
What dogs are these! Where is the rascal cook?
How durst you, villains, bring it from the dresser,
And serve it thus to me that love it not?
There, take it to you, trenchers, cups, and all: Throws the meat, c. about the stage.
You heedless joltheads and unmannered slaves!
What, do you grumble? I'll be with you straight.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I pray you, husband, be not so disquiet:
The meat was well, if you were so contented.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: I tell thee, Kate, 'twas burnt and dried away;
And I expressly am forbid to touch it,
For it engenders choler, planteth anger;
And better 'twere that both of us did fast,
Since, of ourselves, ourselves are choleric,
Than feed it with such overroasted flesh.
Be patient; to-morrow't shall be mended,
And, for this night, we'll fast for company.
Come, I will bring thee to thy bridal chamber. Exeunt. Re-enter Servants severally.

sp.speaker: Nathaniel
sp.ab: Peter, didst ever see the like?

sp.speaker: Peter
sp.ab: He kills her in her own humour,

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Curtis
sp.ab: In her chamber, making a sermon of continency to her;
sp.l: And rails, and swears, and rates, that she, poor soul,
Knows not which way to stand, to look, to speak,
And sits as one new risen from a dream.
Away, away! for he is coming hither. Exeunt. Re-enter PETRUCHIO.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Thus have I politicly begun my reign,
And 'tis my hope to end successfully.
My falcon now is sharp and passing empty;
And till she stoop she must not be full-gorged,
For then she never looks upon her lure.
Another way I have to man my haggard,
To make her come and know her keeper's call,
That is, to watch her, as we watch these kites
That bate and beat and will not be obedient.
She eat no meat to-day, nor none shall eat;
Last night she slept not, nor to-night she shall not;
As with the meat, some undeserved fault
I'll find about the making of the bed;
And here I'll fling the pillow, there the bolster,
This way the coverlet, another way the sheets:
Ay, and amid this hurly I intend
That all is done in reverend care of her;
And in conclusion she shall watch all night:
And if she chance to nod I'll rail and brawl
And with the clamour keep her still awake.
This is a way to kill a wife with kindness;
And thus I'll curb her mad and headstrong humour.
He that knows better how to tame a shrew,
Now let him speak: 'tis charity to show. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Is't possible, friend Licio, that Mistress Bianca
Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?
I tell you, sir, she bears me fair in hand.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Sir, to satisfy you in what I have said,
Stand by and mark the manner of his teaching. Enter BIANCA and LUCENTIO.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: Now, mistress, profit you in what you read?

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: What, master, read you? first resolve me that.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: I read that I profess, the Art to Love.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: And may you prove, sir, master of your art!

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: While you, sweet dear, prove mistress of my heart!

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Quick, proceeders, marry! Now, tell me, I pray,
You that durst swear that your mistress Bianca
Loved none in the world so well as Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: O despiteful love! unconstant womankind
I tell thee, Licio, this is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Mistake no more: I am not Licio,
Nor a musician, as I seem to be;
But one that scorn to live in this disguise,
For such a one as leaves a gentleman,
And makes a god of such a cullion:
Know, sir, that I am called Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Signior Hortensio, I have often heard
Of your entire affection to Bianca;
And since mine eyes are witness of her lightness,
I will with you, if you be so contented,
Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: See, how they kiss and court Signior Lucentio,
Here is my hand, and here I firmly vow
Never to woo her more, but do forswear her,
As one unworthy all the former favours
That I have fondly flattered her withal.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: And here I take the like unfeigned oath,
Never to marry with her though she would entreat:
Fie on her! see, how beastly she doth court him!

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!
For me, that I may surely keep mine oath,
I will be married to a wealthy widow,
Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me
As I have loved this proud disdainful haggard.
And so farewell, Signior Lucentio.
Kindness in women, not their beauteous looks,
Shall win my love: and so I take my leave,
In resolution as I swore before. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Mistress Bianca, bless you with such grace
As 'longeth to a lover's blessed case
Nay, I have ta'en you napping, gentle love,
And have forsworn you with Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Tranio, you jest: but have you both forsworn me?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Mistress, we have.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: Then we are rid of Licio.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: I' faith, he'll have a lusty widow now,
That shall be wooed and wedded in a day.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: God give him joy!

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Ay, and he'll tame her.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: He says so, Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: The taming-school! what, is there such a place?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Ay, mistress, and Petruchio is the master;
That teacheth tricks eleven and twenty long,
To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue. Enter BIONDELLO.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: O master, master, I have watched so long
That I am dog-weary: but at last I spied
An ancient angel coming down the hill,
Will serve the turn.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: What is he, Biondello?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Master, a mercatante, or a pedant,
I know not what; but formal in apparel,
In gait and countenance surely like a father.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: And what of him, Tranio?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: If he be credulous and trust my tale,
I'll make him glad to seem Vincentio,
And give assurance to Baptista Minola,
As if he were the right Vincentio.
Take in your love, and then let me alone. Exeunt Lucentio and Bianca. Enter a Pedant.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: God save you, sir!

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: And you, sir! you are welcome.
Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: Sir, at the farthest for a week or two:
But then up farther, and as far as Rome;
And so to Tripoli, if God lend me life.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: What countryman, I pray?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: Of Mantua.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Of Mantua, sir? marry, God forbid!
And come to Padua, careless of your life?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: My life, sir! how, I pray? for that goes hard.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: 'Tis death for any one in Mantua
To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?
Your ships are stayed at Venice, and the duke,
For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him,
Hath published and proclaimed it openly:
'Tis marvel, but that you are but newly come,
You might have heard it else proclaimed about.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: Alas! sir, it is worse for me than so;
For I have bills for money by exchange
From Florence and must here deliver them.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Well, sir, to do you courtesy,
This will I do, and this I will advise you:
First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: Ay, sir, in Pisa have I often been,
Pisa renowned for grave citizens.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Among them know you one Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: I know him not, but I have heard of him;
A merchant of incomparable wealth.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: He is my father, sir; and, sooth to say,
In countenance somewhat doth resemble you.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: As much as an apple doth an oyster, and all one.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: To save your life in this extremity,
This favour will I do you for his sake;
And think it not the worst of all your fortunes
That you are like to Sir Vincentio.
His name and credit shall you undertake,
And in my house you shall be friendly lodged:
Look that you take upon you as you should;
You understand me, sir: so shall you stay
Till you have done your business in the city:
If this be courtesy, sir, accept of it.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: O sir, I do: and will repute you ever
The patron of my life and liberty.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Then go with me to make the matter good.
This, by the way, I let you understand;
My father is here looked for every day,
To pass assurance of a dower in marriage
'Twixt me and one Baptista's daughter here:
In all these circumstances I'll instruct you:
Go with me to clothe you as becomes you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: No, no, forsooth; I dare not for my life.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: The more my wrong, the more his spite appears:
What, did he marry me to famish me?
Beggars, that come unto my father's door
Upon entreaty have a present alms;
If not, elsewhere they meet with charity:
But I, who never knew how to entreat,
Nor never needed that I should entreat,
Am starved for meat, giddy for lack of sleep,
With oaths kept waking and with brawling fed:
And that which spites me more than all these wants,
He does it under name of perfect love;
As who should say, if I should sleep or eat,
'Twere deadly sickness or else present death.
I prithee go and get me some repast;
I care not what, so it be wholesome food.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: What say you to a neat's foot?

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: 'Tis passing good: I prithee let me have it.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: I fear it is too choleric a meat.
How say you to a fat tripe finely broiled?

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I like it well: good Grumio, fetch it me.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: I cannot tell; I fear 'tis choleric.
What say you to a piece of beef and mustard?

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: A dish that I do love to feed upon.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: Ay, but the mustard is too hot a little.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Why then, the beef, and let the mustard rest.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: Nay then, I will not: you shall have the mustard,
Or else you get no beef of Grumio.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Then both, or one, or any thing thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: Why then, the mustard without the beef.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave, Beats him.
That feed'st me with the very name of meat:
Sorrow on thee and all the pack of you,
That triumph thus upon my misery
Go, get thee gone, I say. Enter PETRUCHIO and HORTENSIO with meat.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: How fares my Kate? What, sweeting, all amort?

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Mistress, what cheer?

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Faith, as cold as can be.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Pluck up thy spirits; look cheerfully upon me.
Here, love; thou seest how diligent I am
To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee:
I am sure, sweet Kate, this kindness merits thanks.
What, not a word? Nay, then thou lovest it not;
And all my pains is sorted to no proof.
Here, take away this dish.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I pray you, let it stand.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: The poorest service is repaid with thanks;
And so shall mine, before you touch the meat.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Signior Petruchio, fie! you are to blame.
Come, Mistress Kate, I'll bear you company.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Eat it up all, Hortensio, if thou lovest me.
Much good do it unto thy gentle heart
Kate, eat apace: and now, my honey love,
Will we return unto thy father's house
And revel it as bravely as the best,
With silken coats and caps and golden rings,
With ruffs and cuffs and fardingales and things;
With scarfs and fans and double change of bravery,
With amber bracelets, beads and all this knavery;
What, hast thou dined? The tailor stays thy leisure,
To deck thy body with his ruffling treasure. Enter Tailor.
Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments;
Lay forth the gown. Enter Haberdasher. What news with you, sir?

sp.speaker: Haberdasher
sp.l: Here is the cap your worship did bespeak.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Why, this was moulded on a porringer;
A velvet dish: fie, fie! 'tis lewd and filthy:
Why, 'tis a cockle or a walnut-shell,
A knack, a toy, a trick, a baby's cap:
Away with it! come, let me have a bigger.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I'll have no bigger: this doth fit the time,
And gentlewomen wear such caps as these.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: When you are gentle, you shall have one too,
And not till then.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: That will not be in haste.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Why, sir, I trust I may have leave to speak;
And speak I will; I am no child, no babe:
Your betters have endured me say my mind,
And if you cannot, best you stop your ears,
My tongue will tell the anger of my heart,
Or else my heart concealing it will break,
And rather than it shall, I will be free
Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Why, thou say'st true; it is a paltry cap,
A custard-coffin, a bauble, a silken pie:
I love thee well, in that thou likest it not.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Love me or love me not, I like the cap;
And it I will have, or I will have none. Exit Haberdasher.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Thy gown? why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't.
O mercy, God! what masquing stuff is here?
What's this? a sleeve? 'tis like a demicannon:
What, up and down, carved like an appletart?
Here's snip and nip and cut and slish and slash,
Like to a censer in a barber's shop:
Why, what a' devil's name, tailor, call'st thou this?

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: I see she's like to have neither cap nor gown.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: You bid me make it orderly and well,
According to the fashion and the time.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Marry, and did; but if you be remembered,
I did not bid you mar it to the time.
Go, hop me over every kennel home,
For you shall hop without my custom, sir:
I'll none of it: hence! make your best of it.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I never saw a better fashioned gown,
More quaint, more pleasing, nor more commendable:
Belike you mean to make a puppet of me.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Why, true; he means to make a puppet of thee.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: She says your worship means to make a puppet of her.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: O monstrous arrogance! Thou liest,
thou thread, thou thimble,
Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!
Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!
Braved in mine own house with a skein of thread?
Away, thou rag, thou quantity, thou remnant;
Or I shall so be-mete thee with thy yard
As thou shalt think on prating whilst thou livest!
I tell thee, I, that thou hast marred her gown.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: Your worship is deceived; the gown is made
Just as my master had direction:
Grumio gave order how it should be done.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: I gave him no order; I gave him the stuff.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: But how did you desire it should be made?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Marry, sir, with needle and thread.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: But did you not request to have it cut?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Thou hast faced many things.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: I have.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Face not me: thou hast braved many men; brave
not me; I will neither be faced nor braved. I
say unto thee, I bid thy master cut out the gown;
but I did not bid him cut it to pieces: ergo, thou
liest.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: Why, here is the note of the fashion to testify.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Read it.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: The note lies in's throat, if he say I said so.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: “Imprimis, a loose-bodied gown:”

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Master, if ever I said loose-bodied gown, sew me
in the skirts of it, and beat me to death with a
bottom of brown thread: I said a gown.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: “With a small compassed cape:”

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: I confess the cape.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: “With a trunk sleeve:”

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: I confess two sleeves.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: “The sleeves curiously cut.”

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Ay, there's the villainy.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill. I
commanded the sleeves should be cut out and sewed
up again; and that I'll prove upon thee, though thy
little finger be armed in a thimble.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.ab: This is true that I say: an I had thee in place where,
thou shouldst know it.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: I am for thee straight: take thou the bill, give me
thy mete-yard, and spare not me.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.ab: God-a-mercy, Grumio! then he shall have no odds.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Well, sir, in brief, the gown is not for me.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: You are i' the right, sir; 'tis for my mistress.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Go, take it up unto thy master's use.

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.ab: Villain, not for thy life: take up my mistress' gown
for thy master's use!

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Why, sir, what's your conceit in that?

sp.speaker: Grumio
sp.l: O, sir, the conceit is deeper than you think for:
Take up my mistress' gown to his master's use!
O, fie, fie, fie!

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Hortensio, say thou wilt see the tailor paid.
Go take it hence; be gone, and say no more.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Tailor, I'll pay thee for thy gown to-morrow:
Take no unkindness of his hasty words:
Away! I say; commend me to thy master. Exit Tailor.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Well, come, my Kate; we will unto your father's
Even in these honest mean habiliments:
Our purses shall be proud, our garments poor;
For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich;
And as the sun breaks through the darkest clouds,
So honour peereth in the meanest habit.
What is the jay more precious than the lark,
Because his feathers are more beautiful?
Or is the adder better than the eel,
Because his painted skin contents the eye?
O, no, good Kate; neither art thou the worse
For this poor furniture and mean array,
If thou accountedst it shame, lay it on me;
And therefore frolic: we will hence forthwith,
To feast and sport us at thy father's house.
Go, call my men, and let us straight to him;
And bring our horses unto Long-lane end;
There will we mount, and thither walk on foot.
Let's see; I think 'tis now some seven o'clock,
And well we may come there by dinnertime.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I dare assure you, sir, 'tis almost two;
And 'twill be suppertime ere you come there.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: It shall be seven ere I go to horse:
Look, what I speak, or do, or think to do,
You are still crossing it. Sirs, let't alone:
I will not go to-day; and ere I do,
It shall be what o'clock I say it is.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Why, so this gallant will command the sun. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter TRANIO, and the Pedant dressed like VINCENTIO.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Sir, this is the house: please it you that I call?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: Ay, what else? and but I be deceived
Signior Baptista may remember me,
Near twenty years ago, in Genoa,
Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: 'Tis well; and hold your own, in any case,
With such austerity as 'longeth to a father.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: I warrant you. Enter BIONDELLO.
But, sir, here comes your boy;
'Twere good he were schooled.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello,
Now do your duty throughly, I advise you:
Imagine 'twere the right Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Tut, fear not me.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: But hast thou done thy errand to Baptista?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: I told him that your father was at Venice,
And that you looked for him this day in Padua.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Th' art a tall fellow: hold thee that to drink.
Here comes Baptista: set your countenance, sir. Enter BAPTISTA and LUCENTIO.
Signior Baptista, you are happily met. To the Pedant
Sir, this is the gentleman I told you of:
I pray you, stand good father to me now,
Give me Bianca for my patrimony.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.l: Soft, son!
Sir, by your leave: having come to Padua
To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio
Made me acquainted with a weighty cause
Of love between your daughter and himself:
And, for the good report I hear of you
And for the love he beareth to your daughter
And she to him, to stay him not too long,
I am content, in a good father's care,
To have him matched; and if you please to like
No worse than I, upon some agreement
Me shall you find ready and willing
With one consent to have her so bestowed;
For curious I cannot be with you,
Signior Baptista, of whom I hear so well.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: Sir, pardon me in what I have to say:
Your plainness and your shortness please me well.
Right true it is, your son Lucentio here
Doth love my daughter and she loveth him,
Or both dissemble deeply their affections:
And therefore, if you say no more than this,
That like a father you will deal with him
And pass my daughter a sufficient dower,
The match is made, and all is done:
Your son shall have my daughter with consent.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: I thank you, sir. Where then do you know best
We be affied and such assurance ta'en
As shall with either part's agreement stand?

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: Not in my house, Lucentio; for, you know,
Pitchers have ears, and I have many servants:
Besides, old Gremio is hearkening still;
And happily we might be interrupted.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Then at my lodging, an it like you:
There doth my father lie; and there, this night,
We'll pass the business privately and well.
Send for your daughter by your servant here;
My boy shall fetch the scrivener presently.
The worst is this, that, at so slender warning,
You are like to have a thin and slender pittance.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: It likes me well. Cambio, hie you home,
And bid Bianca make her ready straight:
And, if you will, tell what hath happened,
Lucentio's father is arrived in Padua,
And how she's like to be Lucentio's wife.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: I pray the gods she may with all my heart!

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone. Exit Bion.
Signior Baptista, shall I lead the way?
Welcome! one mess is like to be your cheer:
Come, sir; we will better it in Pisa.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: I follow you. Exeunt Tranio, Pedant, and Baptista. Re-enter BIONDELLO.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Cambio!

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: What sayest thou, Biondello?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: Biondello, what of that?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Faith, nothing; but he's left me here behind, to
expound the meaning or moral of his signs and tokens.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: I pray thee, moralize them.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Then thus. Baptista is safe, talking with the
deceiving father of a deceitful son.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: And what of him?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: His daughter is to be brought by you to the supper.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: And then?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: The old priest of Saint Luke's church is at your
command at all hours.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: And what of all this?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: I cannot tell; except they are busied about a
counterfeit assurance: take you assurance of her,
“cum privilegio ad imprimendum solum:” to the
church; take the priest, clerk, and some sufficient
honest witnesses:
sp.l: If this be not that you look for, I have no more to say,
But bid Bianca farewell for ever and a day.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: Hearest thou, Biondello?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: I cannot tarry: I knew a wench married in an
afternoon as she went to the garden for parsley
to stuff a rabbit; and so may you, sir: and so,
adieu, sir. My master hath appointed me to go to
Saint Luke's, to bid the priest be ready to come
against you come with your appendix.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: I may, and will, if she be so contented:
She will be pleased; then wherefore should I doubt?
Hap what hap may, I'll roundly go about her:
It shall go hard if Cambio go without her. Exit.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 5
div.stage: Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, HORTENSIO, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Come on, a' God's name; once more toward our father's.
Good Lord, how bright and goodly shines the moon!

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: The moon! the sun: it is not moonlight now.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I know it is the sun that shines so bright.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Now, by my mother's son, and that's myself,
It shall be moon, or star, or what I list,
Or ere I journey to your father's house.
Go on, and fetch our horses back again.
Evermore crossed and crossed; nothing but crossed!

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Say as he says, or we shall never go.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Forward, I pray, since we have come so far,
And be it moon, or sun, or what you please:
And if you please to call it a rush-candle,
Henceforth I vow it shall be so for me.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: I say it is the moon.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: I know it is the moon.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Nay, then you lie: it is the blessed sun.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Then, God be blessed, it is the blessed sun:
But sun it is not, when you say it is not;
And the moon changes even as your mind.
What you will have it named, even that it is;
And so it shall be so for Katharine.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Petruchio, go thy ways; the field is won.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Well, forward, forward! thus the bowl should run,
And not unluckily against the bias.
But, soft! company is coming here. Enter VINCENTIO. To Vincentio
Good morrow, gentle mistress: where away?
Tell me, sweet Kate, and tell me truly too,
Hast thou beheld a fresher gentlewoman?
Such war of white and red within her cheeks!
What stars do spangle heaven with such beauty,
As those two eyes become that heavenly face?
Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee.
Sweet Kate, embrace her for her beauty's sake.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.ab: 'A will make the man mad, to make a woman of him.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Young budding virgin, fair and fresh and sweet,
Whither away, or where is thy abode?
Happy the parents of so fair a child;
Happier the man, whom favourable stars
Allots thee for his lovely bedfellow!

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Why, how now, Kate! I hope thou art not mad:
This is a man, old, wrinkled, faded, withered,
And not a maiden, as thou say'st he is.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Pardon, old father, my mistaking eyes,
That have been so bedazzled with the sun
That every thing I look on seemeth green:
Now I perceive thou art a reverend father;
Pardon, I pray thee, for my mad mistaking.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Do, good old grandsire; and withal make known
Which way thou travellest: if along with us,
We shall be joyful of thy company.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Fair sir, and you my merry mistress,
That with your strange encounter much amazed me,
My name is called Vincentio; my dwelling Pisa;
And bound I am to Padua; there to visit
A son of mine, which long I have not seen.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Lucentio, gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Happily met; the happier for thy son.
And now by law, as well as reverend age,
I may entitle thee my loving father:
The sister to my wife, this gentlewoman,
Thy son by this hath married. Wonder not,
Nor be not grieved: she is of good esteem,
Her dowry wealthy, and of worthy birth;
Beside, so qualified as may beseem
The spouse of any noble gentleman.
Let me embrace with old Vincentio,
And wander we to see thy honest son,
Who will of thy arrival be full joyous.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: But is this true? or is it else your pleasure,
Like pleasant travellers, to break a jest
Upon the company you overtake?

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: I do assure thee, father, so it is.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Come, go along, and see the truth hereof;
For our first merriment hath made thee jealous. Exeunt all but Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Well, Petruchio, this has put me in heart.
Have to my widow! and if she be froward,
Then hast thou taught Hortensio to be untoward. Exit.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 1
div.stage: GREMIO discovered. Enter behind BIONDELLO, LUCENTIO, and BIANCA.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Softly and swiftly, sir; for the priest is ready.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: I fly, Biondello: but they may chance to need thee at
home; therefore leave us.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Nay, faith, I'll see the church a' your back;
and then come back to my master's as soon as I can.

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.l: I marvel Cambio comes not all this while. Enter PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, VINCENTIO, GRUMIO, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Sir, here's the door, this is Lucentio's house:
My father's bears more toward the marketplace;
Thither must I, and here I leave you, sir.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: You shall not choose but drink before you go:
I think I shall command your welcome here,
And, by all likelihood, some cheer is toward. Knocks.

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.ab: They're busy within; you were best knock louder.
sp.stage: Pedant looks out of the window.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: What's he that knocks as he would beat down the gate?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Is Signior Lucentio within, sir?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: He's within, sir, but not to be spoken withal.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: What if a man bring him a hundred pound or two, to
make merry withal?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: Keep your hundred pounds to yourself: he shall need
none, so long as I live.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Nay, I told you your son was well beloved in
Padua. Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous
circumstances, I pray you, tell Signior Lucentio
that his father is come from Pisa and is here at the
door to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here
looking out at the window.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Art thou his father?

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: Ay, sir; so his mother says, if I may believe her.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Why, how now, gentleman! why, this is flat knavery, to
take upon you another man's name.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: Lay hands on the villain: I believe 'a means to cozen
somebody in this city under my countenance.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: I have seen them in the church together: God send
'em good shipping! But who is here? mine old
master Vincentio! now we are undone and brought to
nothing.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Come hither, crack-hemp.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: I hope I may choose, sir.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Come hither, you rogue. What, have you forgot me?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for I
never saw you before in all my life.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: What, you notorious villain, didst thou never see thy
master's father, Vincentio?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: What, my old worshipful old master? yes, marry, sir:
see where he looks out of the window.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Is't so, indeed?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Help, help, help! here's a madman will murder me.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: Help, son! help, Signior Baptista!

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.ab: Prithee, Kate, let's stand aside and see the end of
this controversy.
sp.stage: Re-enter Pedant below; TRANIO, BAPTISTA, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Sir, what are you that offer to beat my servant?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: What am I, sir! nay, what are you, sir? O immortal
gods! O fine villain! A silken doublet! a velvet
hose! a scarlet cloak! and a copatain hat! O, I
am undone! I am undone! while I play the good
husband at home, my son and my servant spend all at
the university.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: How now! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.ab: What, is the man lunatic?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Sir, you seem a sober ancient gentleman by your
habit, but your words show you a madman. Why,
sir, what 'cerns it you if I wear pearl and gold? I
thank my good father, I am able to maintain it.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.ab: You mistake, sir, you mistake, sir. Pray, what do you
think is his name?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: His name! as if I knew not his name: I have
brought him up ever since he was three years old, and
his name is Tranio.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: Away, away, mad ass! his name is Lucentio; and
he is mine only son, and heir to the lands of me,
Signior Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Lucentio! O, he hath murdered his master! Lay
hold on him, I charge you, in the duke's name.
O, my son, my son! Tell me thou villain, where is my
son Lucentio?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Call forth an officer.
Carry this mad knave to the gaol. Father Baptista, I
charge you see that he be forthcoming.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Carry me to the gaol!

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.ab: Stay, officer: he shall not go to prison.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.ab: Talk not, Signior Gremio: I say he shall go to prison.

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.ab: Take heed, Signior Baptista, lest you be cony-catched
in this business: I dare swear this is the right
Vincentio.

sp.speaker: Pedant
sp.ab: Swear, if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.ab: Nay, I dare not swear it.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: Then thou wert best say that I am not Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.ab: Yes, I know thee to be Signior Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.ab: Away with the dotard! to the gaol with him!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Thus strangers may be haled and abused: O monstrous
villain!
sp.stage: Re-enter BIONDELLO, with LUCENTIO and BIANCA.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.ab: O! we are spoiled and — yonder he is: deny him, forswear
him, or else we are all undone.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: Pardon, sweet father.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Lives my sweet son? Exeunt Biondello, Tranio, and Pedant, as fast as may be.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Pardon, dear father.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: How hast thou offended?
Where is Lucentio?

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: Here's Lucentio,
Right son to the right Vincentio;
That have by marriage made thy daughter mine,
While counterfeit supposes bleared thine eyne.

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.l: Here's packing, with a witness, to deceive us all!

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Where is that damned villain Tranio,
That faced and braved me in this matter so?

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: Why, tell me, is not this my Cambio?

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Cambio is changed into Lucentio.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: Love wrought these miracles. Bianca's love
Made me exchange my state with Tranio,
While he did bear my countenance in the town;
And happily I have arrived at the last
Unto the wished haven of my bliss.
What Tranio did, myself enforced him to;
Then pardon him, sweet father, for my sake.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: I'll slit the villain's nose, that would have sent me
to the gaol.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.ab: But do you hear, sir? have you married my daughter
without asking my good will?

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.ab: Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but I
will in, to be revenged for this villainy.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.ab: And I, to sound the depth of this knavery.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.ab: Look not pale, Bianca; thy father will not frown.

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.l: My cake is dough; but I'll in among the rest,
Out of hope of all, but my share of the feast. Exit.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Husband, let's follow, to see the end of this ado.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: First kiss me, Kate, and we will.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: What, in the midst of the street?

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: What, art thou ashamed of me?

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: No, sir, God forbid; but ashamed to kiss.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Why, then, let's home again. Come, sirrah, let's away.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Nay, I will give thee a kiss: now pray thee, love, stay.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Is not this well? Come, my sweet Kate:
Better once than never, for never too late. Exeunt,

div.head: Act 5, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter BAPTISTA, VINCENTIO, GREMIO, the Pedant, LUCENTIO, BIANCA, PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, HORTENSIO, and Widow, TRANIO, BIONDELLO, and GRUMIO: the servingmen with Tranio bringing in a banquet.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: At last, though long, our jarring notes agree:
And time it is, when raging war is done,
To smile at scapes and perils overblown.
My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome,
While I with selfsame kindness welcome thine.
Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina,
And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow,
Feast with the best, and welcome to my house:
My banquet is to close our stomachs up,
After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down;
For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Then never trust me, if I be afeard.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense:
I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Roundly replied.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Mistress, how mean you that?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Thus I conceive by him.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: “He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:”
I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Your husband, being troubled with a shrew,
Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe:
And now you know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: A very mean meaning.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Right, I mean you.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: To her, Kate!

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: To her, widow!

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: That's my office.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Spoke like an officer: ha' to thee, lad! Drinks to Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.l: Believe me. sir, they butt together well.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Head, and butt! an hasty-witted body
Would say your head and butt were head and horn.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awakened you?

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Nay, that you shall not: since you have begun,
Have at you for a bitter jest or two!

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush;
And then pursue me as you draw your bow.
You are welcome all. Exeunt Bianca, Katharina, and Widow.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio,
This bird you aimed at, though you hit her not;
Therefore a health to all that shot and missed.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: O, sir, Lucentio slipped me like his greyhound,
Which runs himself and catches for his master.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: A good swift simile, but something currish.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: 'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself:
'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: 'A has a little galled me, I confess;
And, as the jest did glance away from me,
'Tis ten to one it maimed you two outright.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio,
I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Well, I say no: and therefore for assurance
Let's each one send unto his wife;
And he whose wife is most obedient
To come at first when he doth send for her,
Shall win the wager which we will propose.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Content. What's the wager?

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: Twenty crowns.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Twenty crowns!
I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound,
But twenty times so much upon my wife.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: A hundred then.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: A match! 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Who shall begin?

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: That will I.
Go. Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: I go. Exit.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: Son, I'll be your half. Bianca comes.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself. Re-enter BIONDELLO.
How now! what news?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: Sir, my mistress sends you word
That she is busy and she cannot come.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: How! she is busy and she cannot come!
Is that an answer?

sp.speaker: Gremio
sp.l: Ay, and a kind one too:
Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: I hope, better.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife
To come to me forthwith. Exit Bion.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: O, ho! entreat her!
Nay, then she must needs come.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: I am afraid, sir,
Do what you can, yours will not be entreated. Re-enter BIONDELLO.
Now, where's my wife?

sp.speaker: Tranio
sp.l: She says you have some goodly jest in hand:
She will not come; she bids you come to her.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile,
Intolerable, not to be endured!
Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress;
Say, I command her come to me. Exit Grumio.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: I know her answer.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: She will not.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina! Re-enter KATHARINA.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: They sit conferring by the parlour fire.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Go, fetch them hither: if they deny to come,
Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands:
Away, I say, and bring them hither straight. Exit Katharina.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Marry, peace it bodes, and love and quiet life:
An awful rule and right supremacy;
And, to be short, what not, that's sweet and happy?

sp.speaker: Baptista
sp.l: Now, fair befall thee, good Petruchio!
The wager thou hast won; and I will add
Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns;
Another dowry to another daughter,
For she is changed, as she had never been.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Nay, I will win my wager better yet
And show more sign of her obedience,
Her new-built virtue and obedience.
See where she comes and brings your froward wives
As prisoners to her womanly persuasion. Re-enter KATHARINA, with BIANCA and Widow
Katharina, that cap of yours becomes you not:
Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh,
Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: I would your duty were as foolish too:
The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca,
Hath cost me an hundred crowns since suppertime.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: The more fool you, for laying on my duty.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Katharine, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women
What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Come on, I say; and first begin with her.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: She shall not.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: I say she shall: and first begin with her.

sp.speaker: Katharina
sp.l: Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow,
And dart not scornful glances from those eyes,
To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor:
It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads,
Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds,
And in no sense is meet or amiable.
A woman moved is like a fountain troubled,
Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty;
And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty
Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it.
Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee,
And for thy maintenance commits his body
To painful labour both by sea and land,
To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,
Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe;
And craves no other tribute at thy hands
But love, fair looks and true obedience;
Too little payment for so great a debt.
Such duty as the subject owes the prince
Even such a woman oweth to her husband;
And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour,
And not obedient to his honest will,
What is she but a foul contending rebel
And graceless traitor to her loving lord?
I am ashamed that women are so simple
To offer war where they should kneel for peace,
Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway,
When they are bound to serve, love and obey.
Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth,
Unapt to toil and trouble in the world,
But that our soft conditions and our hearts
Should well agree with our external parts?
Come, come, you froward and unable worms
My mind hath been as big as one of yours,
My heart as great, my reason haply more,
To bandy word for word and frown for frown;
But now I see our lances are but straws,
Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare,
That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot,
And place your hands below your husband's foot:
In token of which duty, if he please,
My hand is ready; may it do him ease.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: Well, go thy ways, old lad; for thou shalt ha't.

sp.speaker: Vincentio
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

sp.speaker: Petruchio
sp.l: Come, Kate, we'll to bed.
We three are married, but you two are sped. To Luc.
'Twas I won the wager, though you hit the white;
And, being a winner, God give you good night! Exeunt Petruchio and Katharina.

sp.speaker: Hortensio
sp.l: Now, go thy ways; thou hast tamed a curst shrew.

sp.speaker: Lucentio
sp.l: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so. Exeunt.
